title: Galena
text:
Galena, also called lead glance, is the natural mineral form of <a href="lead%28II%29%20sulfide">lead(II) sulfide</a> (PbS). It is the most important <a href="ore">ore</a> of <a href="lead">lead</a> and an important source of <a href="silver">silver</a>.
Galena is one of the most abundant and widely distributed <a href="sulfide%20mineral">sulfide mineral</a>s. It crystallizes in the <a href="Cubic%20%28crystal%20system%29">cubic</a> <a href="crystal%20system">crystal system</a> often showing <a href="octahedral">octahedral</a> forms. It is often associated with the minerals <a href="sphalerite">sphalerite</a>, <a href="calcite">calcite</a> and <a href="fluorite">fluorite</a>.
Lead ore deposits.
Galena is the main ore of <a href="lead">lead</a>, used since ancient times, since lead can be <a href="smelted">smelted</a> from galena in an ordinary wood fire. Galena typically is found in <a href="hydrothermal%20vein">hydrothermal vein</a>s in association with <a href="sphalerite">sphalerite</a>, <a href="marcasite">marcasite</a>, <a href="chalcopyrite">chalcopyrite</a>, <a href="cerussite">cerussite</a>, <a href="anglesite">anglesite</a>, <a href="dolomite%20%28mineral%29">dolomite</a>, <a href="calcite">calcite</a>, <a href="quartz">quartz</a>, <a href="barite">barite</a>, and <a href="fluorite">fluorite</a>. It is also found in association with sphalerite in low-temperature lead-<a href="zinc">zinc</a> deposits within <a href="limestone">limestone</a> beds. Minor amounts are found in <a href="contact%20metamorphic">contact metamorphic</a> zones, in <a href="pegmatite">pegmatite</a>s, and disseminated in sedimentary rock.
In some deposits the galena contains up to 0.5% <a href="silver">silver</a>, a byproduct that far surpasses the main lead ore in revenue. In these deposits significant amounts of silver occur as included <a href="silver%20sulfide">silver sulfide</a> mineral phases or as limited silver in <a href="solid%20solution">solid solution</a> within the galena structure. These argentiferous galenas have long been an important ore of silver.Silver-bearing galena is almost entirely of hydrothermal origin; galena in lead-zinc deposits contains little silver.
Galena deposits are found worldwide in various environments. Noted deposits include those at <a href="Freiberg">Freiberg</a> in <a href="Saxony">Saxony</a>; <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, the <a href="Mendip%20Hills">Mendip</a>s in <a href="Somerset">Somerset</a>, <a href="Derbyshire">Derbyshire</a>, and <a href="Cumberland">Cumberland</a> in <a href="England">England</a>; the <a href="Madan%2C%20Smolyan%20Province">Madan</a> and <a href="Rhodope%20Mountains">Rhodope Mountains</a> in <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>; the <a href="Sullivan%20Mine">Sullivan Mine</a> of <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>; <a href="Broken%20Hill%20ore%20deposit">Broken Hill</a> and <a href="Mount%20Isa%20Mines">Mount Isa</a> in <a href="Australia">Australia</a>; and the ancient <a href="History%20of%20mining%20in%20Sardinia">mines of Sardinia</a>. 
In the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, it occurs most notably as lead-zinc ore in the <a href="Carbonate%20hosted%20lead%20zinc%20ore%20deposits">Mississippi Valley type deposits</a> of the <a href="Lead%20Belt">Lead Belt</a> in southeastern <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>, which is the largest known deposit, and in the <a href="Driftless%20Area">Driftless Area</a> of <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="Iowa">Iowa</a> and <a href="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>. Galena also was a major mineral of the <a href="zinc">zinc</a>-lead mines of the <a href="tri-state%20district">tri-state district</a> around <a href="Joplin%2C%20Missouri">Joplin</a> in southwestern Missouri and the adjoining areas of <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a> and <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>. Galena is also an important ore mineral in the silver mining regions of <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>, <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a>, <a href="Utah">Utah</a> and <a href="Montana">Montana</a>. Of the latter, the <a href="Coeur%20d%27Alene%2C%20Idaho">Coeur d'Alene</a> district of northern Idaho was most prominent.
Australia is world's leading producer of lead as of 2021, most of which is extracted as galena. Argentiferous galena was accidentally discovered at <a href="Glen%20Osmond">Glen Osmond</a> in 1841, and additional deposits were discovered near <a href="Broken%20Hill">Broken Hill</a> in 1876 and at <a href="Mount%20Isa">Mount Isa</a> in 1923. Most galena in Australia is found in hydrothermal deposits emplaced around 1680 million years ago, which have since been heavily metamorphosed.
The largest documented crystal of galena is composite cubo-octahedra from the <a href="Great%20Laxey%20Mine">Great Laxey Mine</a>, <a href="Isle%20of%20Man">Isle of Man</a>, measuring .
Importance.
Galena is the <a href="List%20of%20U.S.%20state%20minerals%2C%20rocks%2C%20and%20gemstones">official state mineral</a> of the U.S. states of Kansas, <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>, and <a href="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>; the former mining communities of <a href="Galena%2C%20Kansas">Galena, Kansas</a>, and <a href="Galena%2C%20Illinois">Galena, Illinois</a>, take their names from deposits of this mineral.
Crystal structure.
Galena belongs to the <a href="octahedral">octahedral</a> sulfide group of minerals that have metal <a href="ions">ions</a> in octahedral positions, such as the iron sulfide <a href="pyrrhotite">pyrrhotite</a> and the nickel arsenide <a href="niccolite">niccolite</a>. The galena group is named after its most common member, with other <a href="Cubic%20crystal%20system">isometric</a> members that include <a href="manganese">manganese</a> bearing <a href="alabandite">alabandite</a> and <a href="niningerite">niningerite</a>.
Divalent lead (Pb) <a href="cation">cation</a>s and <a href="sulfur">sulfur</a> (S) <a href="anion">anion</a>s form a close-packed cubic <a href="unit%20cell">unit cell</a> much like the mineral <a href="halite">halite</a> of the <a href="halide%20mineral">halide mineral</a> group. <a href="Zinc">Zinc</a>, <a href="cadmium">cadmium</a>, <a href="iron">iron</a>, <a href="copper">copper</a>, <a href="antimony">antimony</a>, <a href="arsenic">arsenic</a>, <a href="bismuth">bismuth</a> and <a href="selenium">selenium</a> also occur in variable amounts in galena. <a href="Selenium">Selenium</a> substitutes for sulfur in the structure constituting a <a href="solid%20solution">solid solution</a> series. The lead <a href="Telluride%20%28chemistry%29">telluride</a> mineral <a href="altaite">altaite</a> has the same crystal structure as galena.
Geochemistry.
Within the <a href="weathering">weathering</a> or <a href="oxidation">oxidation</a> zone galena alters to <a href="anglesite">anglesite</a> (lead sulfate) or <a href="cerussite">cerussite</a> (lead carbonate). Galena exposed to <a href="acid%20mine%20drainage">acid mine drainage</a> can be oxidized to anglesite by naturally occurring <a href="bacteria">bacteria</a> and <a href="archaea">archaea</a>, in a process similar to <a href="bioleaching">bioleaching</a>.
Uses of galena.
One of the oldest uses of galena was in the eye cosmetic <a href="Kohl%20%28cosmetics%29">kohl</a>. In <a href="Ancient%20Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a>, this was applied around the eyes to reduce the glare of the desert sun and to repel flies, which were a potential source of disease.
In <a href="pre-Columbian">pre-Columbian</a> North America, galena was used by <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">indigenous peoples</a> as an ingredient in decorative paints and cosmetics, and widely traded throughout the eastern United States. Traces of galena are frequently found at the <a href="Mississippian%20culture">Mississippian</a> city at <a href="Kincaid%20Mounds">Kincaid Mounds</a> in present-day Illinois. The galena used at the site originated from deposits in southeastern and central Missouri and the Upper Mississippi Valley.
Galena is the primary ore of <a href="lead">lead</a>, and is often mined for its silver content.
It can be used as a source of lead in <a href="ceramic%20glaze">ceramic glaze</a>.
Galena is a <a href="semiconductor">semiconductor</a> with a small <a href="band%20gap">band gap</a> of about 0.4 <a href="Electronvolt">eV</a>, which found use in early <a href="wireless">wireless</a> communication systems. It was used as the crystal in <a href="crystal%20radio">crystal radio</a> receivers, in which it was used as a point-contact <a href="diode">diode</a> capable of rectifying alternating current to <a href="Detector%20%28radio%29">detect</a> the radio signals. The galena crystal was used with a sharp wire, known as a <a href="Cat%27s-whisker%20detector">"cat's whisker"</a> in contact with it.
